100 Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer ^ Notes on elliptic curves.  II
to do SO.  The calculations are straightforward except for the recurrent need to solve equations of the form
( 7.  1 ) + by ^ cz ^ = 0
over the rationals.  One of Lagrange ’ s proofs of his theorem [ 16 ] gives a constructive method of solving ( 7.  1 ) when it is possible.  Alternatively we may search for a solution,  since Holzer [ 14 ] has shown that we need only examine the region
^ I ftc I,  ^ I ca I,  ^\ ab \. 
The local solubility of the coverings was checked by methods similar to those described in our previous paper.  In searching for rational points on the coA ^ erings we considered only relatively small values of the variables ; for we have found that time spent on extending such a search is only meagrely rewarded. 
For each of the values of D considered,  we give in Table 1 the corresponding values of ( T,  g,  Д and Ai,  the last two being the numbers of first descents defined in § 5.  These are also the values of o,  g,  Aj and A respectively corresponding to — 4i ). Let т be the Tamagawa number of as defined in § 7 ; and let rj { D ) be the number of rational points on Pjy of finite order.  ( Thus within the limits of our table 77 4 when D is — 4 or a
square,  and rj = 2 otherwise. ) Rather than take up space printing the values of r { D ) and t (— 4Z )), we have marked the value of a with an asterisk whenever o ’ Ф 0 and r ( D ) or t (— 4Z >) Фг }^( — 4D ). These cases are further described in Table 2 ;
according to our conjectures they are just those in which g = 0 and the Tate-Safarevic group is non-trivial ; Table 2 is possibly less reliable than Table 1. 
We have given the value of g whenever we know it.  A gap instead of the value of g indicates that we do not know it,  and indeed have no information beyond that given by the general inequality
O ^ g ^ A + Ai — 2. 
An entry such as ‘ 1— ’ indicates that ( because of the second descent ) we know that g ^ 1 ; in these cases there is a non-trivial Tate-Safarevic group.  An entry such as ‘ 1 +’ indicates that we know that g ^ 1 since we have actually found a generator. 
In Table 1 we have packed onto each line the entries corresponding to four linked values of D.  In each line the first column gives an odd positive integer Dq.  The re maining sixteen columns form four groups of four.  The first group gives the values of ( T,  g,  A and Aj for D = Dq ] and the other three groups correspond to the cases D = — Dq,  D — 2Dq and D = — 2Dq in that order. 
Let us write y = rj ^ jr ] then the main conjectures of this paper are that y Ф 0 if and only if g = 0,  and that in this case y is the order of the Tate-Safarevic group.  The first part of this agrees with our calculations whenever we know g.  Moreover,  the work of Cassels [ 5 ] strongly suggests that g should have the parity of A - f Aj ; and in our tables y == 0 whenever A + Ai is odd.  For the second part of the conjecture,  we note that in our tables y is always a square ; and Cassels has shown that when the order of the Tate- Safarevic group is finite it is a square.  We have made no attempt to calculate p-coverings for any prime p > 2 ; and the practical difficulties appear to us formidable.  But we do known the 2 - component of the Tate-Safarevic group in every case for which we know that g = 0 ; and this yields always the correct power of 2 in y.  ( The few cases where y Ф 0 but we do not know that g = 0 are ones in which the second descent is indecisive ; it is further corroboration of the conjecture that in these cases y is divisible by a high power of 2. )
